Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sustainability of critical areas for eiders and subsistence hunters in an industrializing nearshore zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout the Arctic, indigenous people are faced with difficult choices between the cash benefits of industrialization versus potential degradation of subsistence hunting. Subsistence hunting often provides a large fraction of foods, and may be more reliable in the long term than a cash economy based on nonrenewable resources. Subsistence hunting for certain species may also have cultural significance that far exceeds their dietary contribution. On the Chukchi Sea coast, pipelines connecting offshore oil wells to onshore terminals must be built across a nearshore corridor used by most marine birds and mammals that migrate to the western North American Arctic. These animals are hunted for subsistence by local Natives. During spring, these animals travel through a zone of open water that forms between landfast ice and moving pack ice. If an oil pipeline were ruptured by spring ice scour in this shallow zone, oil could probably not be removed from open water within broken ice during migration. Such an event could not only restrict the extent of viable habitat, but also eliminate local hunting areas. Thus, key habitats that are usually accessible to hunting should be avoided in pipeline placement. In this research, we will model habitat requirements and map viable prey densities for a formerly hunted but now threatened species (Spectacled Eider, SPEI) and a commonly hunted species (King Eider, KIEI) in the Chukchi nearshore zone, and determine long-term variability in the eiders? access to those areas through the ice. We will refine these maps with traditional ecological knowledge on conditions and areas where hunting for KIEI typically occurs. We will then estimate probabilities that different eider feeding areas that are accessible through the ice and conducive to hunting would be eliminated during migration by oil spills from pipelines built along four alternative routes. We will use this information to inform structured decision-making workshops we will hold in the Native community. These workshops will help create a local vision for sustainability, in terms of potential risks of different pipeline routes to subsistence and cultural values of eiders, relative to cash benefits of local construction projects.

Local villagers will be involved in creating and shaping the data set, and will be the main participants in structured decision-making workshops. We will integrate our work with outreach and education programs conducted in these villages by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Our project will yield important information for future evaluations and decision-making by Endangered Species and Migratory Bird Management Offices. Our modern scientific and traditional ecological data, and facilitation of community consensus-building, will expedite later impact assessments by BOEM and other agencies as oilfield development proceeds. On a hemispheric scale, the approach we develop will serve as a prototype applicable to the many such situations developing across the Arctic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Maintaining the subsistence way of life in a changing Arctic: Structured decision analysis informed by traditional ecological knowledge as a tool to strengthen subsistence systems

For the Indigenous communities of the Arctic, subsistence activities are important for cultural, emotional, and nutritional well-being.  In this study, we engaged with the Alaska Native community of Wainwright to understand and anticipate challenges to the subsistence system under the changing Arctic climate. We introduced Structured Decision Making (SDM) to the community as a way to help build adaptive capacity in a changing environment. Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) informed the SDM process, which provided a framework for discussions to identify and prioritize solutions to meet the goals of the community to maintain the subsistence way of life into the future.  Through the SDM process, our goal was to provide the groundwork for decisions in the form of a well-documented framework for understanding and addressing climate change vulnerabilities.

Through a series of workshops, we asked participants to describe challenges to the subsistence way of life, identify ways in which they are currently dealing with these challenges, and come up with new strategies for strengthening the subsistence system in the future.  Through discussions with workshop participants, we identified specific ways that people are currently adapting to the challenges of hunter safety, changes to wildlife migration, declining availability of certain foods, and thawing ice cellars. People in Wainwright currently use a combination of traditional and modern strategies to adapt to climate change. Our workshops led to greater clarity about the relative importance of factors influencing the health and abundance of key subsistence species and success of hunting activities. A key concern of workshop participants was the changing accessibility and availability of wildlife near Wainwright. This concern was driven by declining sea ice, leading to precarious conditions for hunting and altered migration patterns of subsistence species. Of the five most important subsistence species in Wainwright, one has experienced recent population declines and the harvest of three others depends on the presence of thick, reliable shorefast ice. Workshop participants also raised concerns about employment opportunities that would both support and be compatible with the subsistence lifestyle. Developing a diverse and strong local economy would buffer the community against outside economic factors. 

One major outcome of this project was the documentation of how different hunter safety strategies were prioritized. This process resulted in the community applying for and successfully obtaining funding for safety programs in Wainwright. An additional outcome was the assessment of factors influencing health and accessibility of key subsistence populations, which helps hunters and biologists anticipate the viability of different subsistence foods over the long-term. Our assessment and subsequent report provided a permanent record of TEK collected from experienced hunters and elders in Wainwright.

In this study, SDM informed by TEK was used to help assess the vulnerability of the subsistence system and to prioritize solutions in an Alaska Native community. We propose that SDM provides an effective way to facilitate climate change adaptation, by directly engaging communities to identify specific problems, formulate objectives, and rank alternative adaptive strategies based on conditions unique to their community.  This project served as a test case of SDM in an Arctic Indigenous community, providing a template for strategizing solutions in other communities adapting to climate change in the Arctic. A Post-doctoral Researcher received training with interdisciplinary, collaborative research at the interface between ecological and decision sciences. Information about impacts of climate change and adaptation by Arctic communities was shared with the general public through outreach programs at the Alaska SeaLife Center in Seward, Alaska.
